<div class="c6 " style="margin-bottom:7px">
<!-- <![endif]-->
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
CANNABIS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/19/cannabis-companies-caught-federal-state-regulations?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Pot: Can't Live With It, Can't Live Without It
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<!--[if mso]>
<img alt="South Park marijuana store" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" height=337 src="https://media.giphy.com/media/wiQ4zjfSA5o08/source.gif">
<![endif]-->
<!--[if !mso]>--><!-- -->
<img class="story-header-image" alt="South Park marijuana store" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" src="https://media.giphy.com/media/wiQ4zjfSA5o08/source.gif">
<!--<![endif]-->
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Giphy</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Where federal and state policy meet is like the crack between your stove and countertop: The things that fall down there are out of sight, out of mind. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Well...until a pandemic hits. Policies intended to curb the spread of COVID-19 are highlighting some of the peculiar paradoxes of industries that follow different rules at different levels of government—industries like cannabis.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>Recreational marijuana is legal in 11 U.S. states, and medical use is permitted in 33 (both are allowed in Washington, D.C.). Some states have deemed marijuana businesses "</span><span><a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/23/counts-essential-business?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">essential</a></span><span>" and allowed them to stay open during the shutdown. </span>
</li>
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>However, cannabis remains illegal at the national level. </span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">To recap: necessary for people's livelihoods in some states, breaking the law federally. Or as one law professor put it to the <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/04/14/california-weed-industry-coronavirus/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">WaPo</a>: “Yesterday’s vice is considered today’s essential service.” </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Essential, but not eligible</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">While many cannabis companies saw a boom in the early days of lockdown, <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/no-federal-relief-cannabis-businesses-cry-help-coronavirus-batters-industry-n1180641?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">sales are now dipping</a>. Many are experiencing additional financial pressures adjusting operations to delivery or drive-thru.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px"><span>However, because of their status at the federal level, marijuana companies were not eligible for any of the $350 billion in small business loans made available through the CARES Act.</span></li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out:</strong> Marijuana companies are used to being denied by large institutions: Big banks won’t <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/magazine/where-pot-entrepreneurs-go-when-the-banks-just-say-no.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">touch the stuff</a>, fearing legal blowback. Some small credit unions have stepped in, but the sector still mostly depends on cash transactions. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">What’s next?</h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Pro-cannabis legislators and business owners are <a href="https://www.cnn.com/2020/04/14/business/cannabis-essential-coronavirus-sba-loans-banking/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">pushing for</a> access to Small Business Administration funds that might be included in the next relief package. Also in play is the SAFE Banking Act, a bill that <a href="https://www.marijuanamoment.net/pelosi-wants-marijuana-businesses-included-in-next-coronavirus-relief-bill-congressman-says/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">would keep</a> federal regulators from taking any “adverse action” against financial institutions that work with cannabis companies. It passed the House last year but the Senate is a different story.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">+ Want to learn more? </strong>Sign up for our newsletter <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/?utm_source=morning_brew&utm_medium=newsletter&utm_campaign=retailbrew&email={email}" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Retail Brew</a>, which is going into more detail on cannabis companies later today. </p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
BANKING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/19/lawmakers-near-deal-refuel-ppp?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
PPPlease Fund
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">U.S. lawmakers are nearing an agreement to refill the Paycheck Protection Program’s coffers with $310 billion, days after the first $350 billion evaporated.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Yesterday, Treasury Sec. Steve Mnuchin and Democratic party leaders said the Senate could <a href="https://www.wsj.com/articles/pelosi-says-we-re-close-to-deal-on-small-business-funding-11587301707?mod=hp_lead_pos1&utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">reach a deal</a> as early as today and secure House approval Tuesday. The bill would also include $75 billion for hospitals and $25 billion for increased COVID-19 testing. </p>
<h2 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0">Will they work out Round 1’s kinks? </h2>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Banking execs compared PPP’s opening day to “a stampede through the eye of a needle.” Most small biz relief funds were <a href="https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/small-business-loan-program-ran-out-money-within-minutes-some-n1187051?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">accounted for</a> within minutes, but demand hasn’t dropped off since PPP ran out of funding last Friday.</p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>JPMorgan </span><span><a href="https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/17/jpmorgan-says-it-has-26-billion-in-small-business-applications-left.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">disbursed</a></span><span> $14 billion in loans (more than any other bank)...but still has about $26 billion worth of applications waiting for additional federal funding. </span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">There’s been controversy.</strong> PPP was designed to help companies with <500 employees cover payroll, but several large chains with thousands of employees have <a href="https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/davidmack/coronavirus-small-business-loans-big-companies-potbelly?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">secured maximum payouts</a>. Potbelly, Ruth’s Chris Steak House, and Shake Shack received a combined $40 million in loans.</p>

<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding: 15px;">
<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TRENDS
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/19/mary-meeker-bond-capital-chart-covid19-changes-economy?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Our New World
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding-right:15px;padding-bottom:15px;padding-left:15px;padding-top:0px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">When things are uncertain, we often turn to Mary Meeker to pull away the cobwebs. The venture capitalist, best known for her annual “Internet Trends” report, just released a <a href="https://assets.documentcloud.org/documents/6842117/Our-New-World.pdf?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">paper</a> on COVID-19 with her team at Bond Capital. It was published first by <a href="https://www.axios.com/mary-meeker-coronavirus-trends-report-0690fc96-294f-47e6-9c57-573f829a6d7c.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">Axios</a>.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Our takeaways: </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">We live in a virus’s dream world: </strong>More people are living in cities and traveling <em>between</em> cities than ever before. And viruses don’t need to go through customs.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Scientists are collaborating at warp speed: </strong>They’ve published around 3,000 papers on COVID-19, which is 20x the published research of other infectious diseases at the same point in the public health response. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom has made history: </strong>Its surge ranks among the most remarkable growth stories in the internet age, outpacing even Instagram and <em>Fortnite</em>. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Federal relief was swift and massive: </strong>The U.S.’ $4.3 trillion of monetary and fiscal stimulus = 124% of government revenue in 2019. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><img src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82NDIvY2FyZXNfYWN0LnBuZyIsImJ1Y2tldCI6Im9zbG8tcHJvZHVjdGlvbiJ9" class="img-responsive" width="640" style="width:100% !important;max-width: 640px; width: 100%;" alt="" data-reactroot=""></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;line-height: 22px;"><small> <em>Bond Capital</em> </small></p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Looking ahead...</strong>“It’s hard to know exactly what return to work will look like.” While many businesses will never recover, “there will be new businesses that would have been inconceivable just a few years ago.”</p>

<th class="card" style="text-align:left;font-weight:400;font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#333;display:block;background-color:#fff;border-radius:15px;border:1px solid #e6e6e6;border-collapse:collapse;box-shadow:none;margin-bottom:0px">

<h3 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0">
TESTING
</h3>
<h1 style="font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px">
<a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/19/rhode-island-state-testing-capacity-reopen-research-says?email={{profile.email}}" target="_blank" style="color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;">
<font color="#000000">
Rhode Island: Short on Space, Big on Testing Capacity
</font></a>
</h1>
</td>
</tr>
</table>
<img alt="Rhode Island beach" style="display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;" width="670" class="story-header-image" src="https://dlp31coh2a67q.cloudfront.net/eyJrZXkiOiJ1cGxvYWRzL21lZGl1bS9hc3NldC82NDMvcmhvZGVfaXNsYW5kX2JlYWNoLmpwZWciLCJidWNrZXQiOiJvc2xvLXByb2R1Y3Rpb24iLCJlZGl0cyI6eyJyZXNpemUiOnsid2lkdGgiOjEwMDAsImhlaWdodCI6bnVsbH19fQ==">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;">
<small><em>Town of Narragansett, RI</em></small>
</p>
<table width="100%" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" border="0" style="border-collapse: collapse;">
<tr>
<td style="padding:15px">
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Last Thursday, President Trump <a href="https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/16/trump-issues-guidelines-easing-lockdown-restrictions?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">handed</a> governors the baton to reopen America. But a new study warns states lack the testing capacity to safely relax lockdown restrictions. </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Harvard researchers <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/04/17/us/coronavirus-testing-states.html?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">estimate</a> states need to conduct 152 tests per 100,000 residents daily. But 34 states were conducting fewer than 50 tests per 100,000 people during the week ended April 15.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Just one state meets the threshold. </strong>Faced with the prospect of summer beach walks without Del’s frozen lemonade, Rhode Island mobilized. It's been administering 185 tests per 100,000 residents. </p>
<ul style="margin-top:0;padding-left:30px">
<li style="line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px">
<span>The secret sauce? On April 6, hometown hero CVS Health </span><span><a href="https://www.wpri.com/health/coronavirus/ri-is-only-state-doing-enough-tests-to-safely-reopen-harvard-experts-suggest/?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">opened</a></span><span> a rapid-testing clinic, doubling testing capacity. The state’s also the size of a U-Haul.</span>
</li>
</ul>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Zoom out: </strong>The debate around when to reopen is turning into a 2020 edition of the Federalist Papers. On Sunday, Vice President Pence <a href="https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/19/pence-governors-ramp-up-coronavirus-testing-194340?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">called on governors</a> to mobilize state labs. But Republican and Democratic governors pushed back, insisting they lack supplies needed for widespread testing, like swabs and reagents. Last night, Trump invoked the Defense Production Act to compel private manufacturers to make more swabs.</p>

<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px">Before we go forward, let's go back. Today is the 10th anniversary of the <a href="https://www.epa.gov/enforcement/deepwater-horizon-bp-gulf-mexico-oil-spill?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">explosion</a> of BP’s Deepwater Horizon oil rig, which killed 11 and sent the equivalent of 4 million barrels of oil into the Gulf of Mexico. The spill, often regarded as the worst environmental disaster in U.S. history, <a href="https://www.reuters.com/article/us-bp-deepwaterhorizon/bp-deepwater-horizon-costs-balloon-to-65-billion-idUSKBN1F50NL?utm_source=morning_brew" target="_blank" class="link" rel="noopener" style="border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333">cost</a> BP more than $65 billion.</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Monday: </strong>Boeing resumes production in Washington state; IBM earnings</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Tuesday: </strong>Existing home sales; earnings (Coca-Cola, Netflix, Snap, Chipotle, Travelers)</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Wednesday: </strong>50th anniversary of Earth Day; earnings (Delta, AT&T, Quest Diagnostics) </p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Thursday: </strong>Weekly unemployment claims; new home sales; NFL Draft begins; Ramadan begins; earnings (Intel, Eli Lilly, Domino’s, Southwest, Capital One, Blackstone)</p>
<p style="line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px"><strong style="color:#000">Friday: </strong>Durable goods orders; earnings (Verizon, American Express, Sanofi)</p>

But short sellers (investors betting against the market) haven’t been this aggressive \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/bets-against-the-stock-market-rise-to-highest-level-in-years-11587288601?mod=hp_lead_pos2\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ein years\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e. This week will feature major earnings reports and the return of that nightmare unemployment claims chart on Thursday. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003e\n\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eCOVID-19: \u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003eTotal cases topped 2.3 million worldwide, and the U.S. has reported more than 40,000 deaths. Some countries in Europe are beginning to ease lockdown restrictions, but experts say the U.S. isn’t doing enough tests to do the same.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c/th\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso ]\u003e\u003c! style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:16px;color:#1c7ff2;font-weight:700;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0\"\u003e\nCANNABIS \n\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003ch1 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:24px;color:#333;font-weight:700;margin-bottom:0;line-height:26px;margin-top:8px\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/04/19/cannabis-companies-caught-federal-state-regulations?email={{profile.email}}\" target=\"_blank\" style=\"color:#000000!important;text-decoration:none;border-bottom:none!important;\"\u003e\n\u003cfont color=\"#000000\"\u003e\nPot: Can't Live With It, Can't Live Without It\n\u003c/font\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\n\u003c/h1\u003e\n\u003c/td\u003e\n\u003c/tr\u003e\n\u003c/table\u003e\n\u003c!--[if mso]\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"South Park marijuana store\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" height=337 src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/wiQ4zjfSA5o08/source.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003c!--[if !mso]\u003e--\u003e\u003c!-- --\u003e\n\u003cimg class=\"story-header-image\" alt=\"South Park marijuana store\" style=\"display: block; width: 100%; max-width: 670px;\" width=\"670\" src=\"https://media.giphy.com/media/wiQ4zjfSA5o08/source.gif\"\u003e\n\u003c!--\u003c![endif]--\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;padding-left:10px;margin-top:5px;margin-bottom:0px;line-height:14px;\"\u003e\n\u003csmall\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiphy\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/small\u003e\n\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding:15px\"\u003e\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhere federal and state policy meet is like the crack between your stove and countertop: The things that fall down there are out of sight, out of mind. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWell...until a pandemic hits. Policies intended to curb the spread of COVID-19 are highlighting some of the peculiar paradoxes of industries that follow different rules at different levels of government—industries like cannabis.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eRecreational marijuana is legal in 11 U.S. states, and medical use is permitted in 33 (both are allowed in Washington, D.C.). Some states have deemed marijuana businesses \"\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/daily/stories/2020/03/23/counts-essential-business?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eessential\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\" and allowed them to stay open during the shutdown. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHowever, cannabis remains illegal at the national level. \u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eTo recap: necessary for people's livelihoods in some states, breaking the law federally. Or as one law professor put it to the \u003ca href=\"https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/2020/04/14/california-weed-industry-coronavirus/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eWaPo\u003c/a\u003e: “Yesterday’s vice is considered today’s essential service.” \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eEssential, but not eligible\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eWhile many cannabis companies saw a boom in the early days of lockdown, \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/politics-news/no-federal-relief-cannabis-businesses-cry-help-coronavirus-batters-industry-n1180641?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esales are now dipping\u003c/a\u003e. Many are experiencing additional financial pressures adjusting operations to delivery or drive-thru.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\u003cspan\u003eHowever, because of their status at the federal level, marijuana companies were not eligible for any of the $350 billion in small business loans made available through the CARES Act.\u003c/span\u003e\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out:\u003c/strong\u003e Marijuana companies are used to being denied by large institutions: Big banks won’t \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/04/magazine/where-pot-entrepreneurs-go-when-the-banks-just-say-no.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003etouch the stuff\u003c/a\u003e, fearing legal blowback. Some small credit unions have stepped in, but the sector still mostly depends on cash transactions. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWhat’s next?\u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003ePro-cannabis legislators and business owners are \u003ca href=\"https://www.cnn.com/2020/04/14/business/cannabis-essential-coronavirus-sba-loans-banking/index.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003epushing for\u003c/a\u003e access to Small Business Administration funds that might be included in the next relief package. Also in play is the SAFE Banking Act, a bill that \u003ca href=\"https://www.marijuanamoment.net/pelosi-wants-marijuana-businesses-included-in-next-coronavirus-relief-bill-congressman-says/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ewould keep\u003c/a\u003e federal regulators from taking any “adverse action” against financial institutions that work with cannabis companies. It passed the House last year but the Senate is a different story.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003e+ Want to learn more? \u003c/strong\u003eSign up for our newsletter \u003ca href=\"https://www.morningbrew.com/retail/?utm_source=morning_brew\u0026utm_medium=newsletter\u0026utm_campaign=retailbrew\u0026email={email}\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eRetail Brew\u003c/a\u003e, which is going into more detail on cannabis companies later today. \u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eU.S. lawmakers are nearing an agreement to refill the Paycheck Protection Program’s coffers with $310 billion, days after the first $350 billion evaporated.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eYesterday, Treasury Sec. Steve Mnuchin and Democratic party leaders said the Senate could \u003ca href=\"https://www.wsj.com/articles/pelosi-says-we-re-close-to-deal-on-small-business-funding-11587301707?mod=hp_lead_pos1\u0026utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ereach a deal\u003c/a\u003e as early as today and secure House approval Tuesday. The bill would also include $75 billion for hospitals and $25 billion for increased COVID-19 testing. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003ch2 style=\"font-family:Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;font-size:19px;font-weight:700;color:#000;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px;margin-right:0;margin-left:0\"\u003eWill they work out Round 1’s kinks? \u003c/h2\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eBanking execs compared PPP’s opening day to “a stampede through the eye of a needle.” Most small biz relief funds were \u003ca href=\"https://www.nbcnews.com/business/business-news/small-business-loan-program-ran-out-money-within-minutes-some-n1187051?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eaccounted for\u003c/a\u003e within minutes, but demand hasn’t dropped off since PPP ran out of funding last Friday.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eJPMorgan \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.cnbc.com/2020/04/17/jpmorgan-says-it-has-26-billion-in-small-business-applications-left.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003edisbursed\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e $14 billion in loans (more than any other bank)...but still has about $26 billion worth of applications waiting for additional federal funding. \u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eThere’s been controversy.\u003c/strong\u003e PPP was designed to help companies with \u003c500 employees cover payroll, but several large chains with thousands of employees have \u003ca href=\"https://www.buzzfeednews.com/article/davidmack/coronavirus-small-business-loans-big-companies-potbelly?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003esecured maximum payouts\u003c/a\u003e. And viruses don’t need to go through customs.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eScientists are collaborating at warp speed: \u003c/strong\u003eThey’ve published around 3,000 papers on COVID-19, which is 20x the published research of other infectious diseases at the same point in the public health response. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom has made history: \u003c/strong\u003eIts surge But a new study warns states lack the testing capacity to safely relax lockdown restrictions. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003eHarvard researchers \u003ca href=\"https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/04/17/us/coronavirus-testing-states.html?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eestimate\u003c/a\u003e states need to conduct 152 tests per 100,000 residents daily. But 34 states were conducting fewer than 50 tests per 100,000 people during the week ended April 15.\u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eJust one state meets the threshold. \u003c/strong\u003eFaced with the prospect of summer beach walks without Del’s frozen lemonade, Rhode Island mobilized. It's been administering 185 tests per 100,000 residents. \u003c/p\u003e\r\n\u003cul style=\"margin-top:0;padding-left:30px\"\u003e\r\n\u003cli style=\"line-height:22px;margin-bottom:10px\"\u003e\n\u003cspan\u003eThe secret sauce? On April 6, hometown hero CVS Health \u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e\u003ca href=\"https://www.wpri.com/health/coronavirus/ri-is-only-state-doing-enough-tests-to-safely-reopen-harvard-experts-suggest/?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003eopened\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/span\u003e\u003cspan\u003e a rapid-testing clinic, doubling testing capacity. The state’s also the size of a U-Haul.\u003c/span\u003e\n\u003c/li\u003e\r\n\u003c/ul\u003e\r\n\u003cp style=\"line-height:22px;margin-top:0;margin-bottom:15px\"\u003e\u003cstrong style=\"color:#000\"\u003eZoom out: \u003c/strong\u003eThe debate around when to reopen is turning into a 2020 edition of the Federalist Papers. On Sunday, Vice President Pence \u003ca href=\"https://www.politico.com/news/2020/04/19/pence-governors-ramp-up-coronavirus-testing-194340?utm_source=morning_brew\" target=\"_blank\" class=\"link\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"border-bottom:2px solid #1c7ff2;text-decoration:none;color:#333\"\u003ecalled on governors\u003c/a\u003e to mobilize state labs. But Republican and Democratic governors pushed back, insisting they lack supplies needed for widespread testing, like swabs and reagents. Last night, Trump invoked the Defense Production Act to compel private manufacturers to make more swabs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003c!-- SOCIAL LINKS --\u003e\n\u003ctable width=\"100%\" cellpadding=\"0\" cellspacing=\"0\" border=\"0\" style=\"border-collapse: collapse;\"\u003e\n\u003ctr\u003e\n\u003ctd style=\"padding-top: 12px;\"\u003e\n\u003ca href=\"https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.morningbrew.com%2Fdaily%2Fstories%2F2020%2F04%2F19%2Frhode-island-state-testing-capacity-reopen-research-says\" target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener\" style=\"text-decoration: none;\" class=\"\"\u003e\n\u003cimg alt=\"\" style=\"display: inline-block;
